title: Ambiguity errors in 2018 uniform import paths are not technically necessary

labels.name: T-lang
labels.description: Relevant to the language team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: C-tracking-issue
labels.description: Category: A tracking issue for an RFC or an unstable feature.

labels.name: S-tracking-needs-summary
labels.description: It's hard to tell what's been done and what hasn't! Someone should do some investigation.

body:
Right now import resolution on 2018 edition fails with an ambiguity error if multiple candidates are found:
```rust
struct S; // Outer

fn main() {
    struct S; // Inner

    use S as Z; // ERROR `S` is ambiguous (name vs any other name during import resolution)

    let s = S; // OK, the Inner S is preferred
}
```

This is different from non-import paths in which resolutions from closer scopes are preferred without errors.

This restriction is technically unnecessary and exists because some people were uncomfortable with disambiguation happening in import paths specifically (see previous threads, ... many of them, https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/55618 being the latest one).

This restriction can be lifted fully or partially if it causes too much trouble in practice with ambiguity errors, or with addition of new names to libraries being backward-incompatible due to new ambiguities.

(By "partially" I mean e.g. "disambiguation is okay, unless one of the candidates is an extern crate" or something like that.)
